required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acetaminophen and AKI After Aortic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Acetaminophen on the Incidence of Acute Kidney Injury in Patients Undergoing Aortic Surgery With Moderate Hypothermic Circulatory Arrest

brief_summary.textblock:
Acute kidney injury is commonly accompanied major complication after aortic surgery.
Cardipulmonary bypass lyses erythrocyte and induces lipid peroxidation. This increases plasma free hemoglobin, F2-isoprostane, and isofuran concentration. Cell free hemoglobin have been reported to be associated with poor prognosis such as acute kidney injury, myocardial infarction, and death.
Acetaminophen is reported to attenuate hemeprotein mediated lipid peroxidation. Thus, investigators hypothesized that acetaminophen might have protective effect on the incidence of acute kidney injury in patients undergoing aortic surgery with moderate hypothermic circulatory arrest.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of acute kidney injury after aortic surgery with moderate hypothermic circulatory arrest
primary_outcome.description: Compare the incidence of acute kidney injury within 7 days after surgery. Acute kidney injury is defined using KDIGO criteria.

arm_group.description: patients receiving equal amount of normal saline

intervention.description: Acetaminophen 1g IV every 6 hours for a weight > 50kg (maximum of 4g per 24 hours) or 15mg/kg every 6 hours for a weight < 50kg (maximum of 75mg/kg per 24 hours)
Normal saline 100 ml (equal amount of acetaminophen) IV every 6 hours

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1) Patients undergoing aortic surgery with moderate hypothermic circulatory arrest.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. patients with chronic kidney disease or with dialysis, eGFR < 15ml/min/1.73m2
2. allergy to acetaminophen or propacetamol HCl
3. history of liver cirrhosis or total bilirubin > 2.0mg/dL
3) patients taking acetaminophen or diclofenac 4) patients who cannot understand informed consent

reference.citation: Simpson SA, Zaccagni H, Bichell DP, Christian KG, Mettler BA, Donahue BS, Roberts LJ 2nd, Pretorius M. Acetaminophen attenuates lipid peroxidation in children undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2014 Jul;15(6):503-10. doi: 10.1097/PCC.0000000000000149.
